Selling a product starts with a GS1 barcode number

The sound of a beep at the checkout counter. The GS1 barcode launched a digital revolution that forever changed the way the world does business. With a simple scan a product could be identified and connected to a computerised system.

Companies of all sizes need barcode numbers to correctly identify and sell their products in stores or online. The power of the data captured through the barcode is helping to solve large and complex industry challenges.

Let's keep this incredible momentum and outline the APIs for the tables that manage the flow of royalty statements and money. We'll use the same consistent RESTful CRUD approach:
* POST /api/royalty_sources: Add a new royalty source (DSP
* GET /api/royalty_sources: List all royalty sources (with filters for source_type).
* GET /api/royalty_sources/<source_uuid>: Get details of a specific source.
* DELETE /api/royalty_sources/<source_uuid>: Delete a source (if not linked to statements
* POST /api/royalty_statements: Record a new incoming royalty statement header. (Request body would include royalty_source_id
* GET /api/royalty_statements: List all statements (filterable by source
* GET /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Get a specific statement header (this endpoint could also be designed to optionally fetch its associated lines).
* PUT /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Update statement header info or status.
* DELETE /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Delete a statement (this would also delete its lines due to ON DELETE CASCADE in our SQL).

* GET /api/royalty_statements: List all statements (filterable by source
* GET /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Get a specific statement header (this endpoint could also be designed to optionally fetch its associated lines).

* DELETE /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Delete a statement (this would also delete its lines due to ON DELETE CASCADE in our SQL).

the next step is to sketch out how your main Python backend file, let's call it backend/app.py, will be structured. This file will use Flask to create the API that your Next.js/React frontend will talk to.

Here's a high-level outline of what backend/app.py would contain:

Python

# backend/app.py
import os
from flask import Flask, request, jsonify
from flask_cors import CORS
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from supabase import create_client, Client
import google.generativeai as genai # For Gemini AI features later
import logging

# --- 1. Basic Configuration & Initialization ---
load_dotenv() # Load environment variables from .env file (for API keys)

# Initialize Flask App
app = Flask(__name__)
CORS(app) # Enable CORS for requests from your Electron/Next.js frontend

# Logging Configuration
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.INFO, format='%(asctime)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s')

# --- 2. Initialize External Services ---

# Supabase Client Initialization
SUPABASE_URL = os.getenv(SUPABASE_URL")

Next Up: API Endpoints for the Core Royalty Flow Tables!
Let's keep this incredible momentum and outline the APIs for the tables that manage the flow of royalty statements and money. We'll use the same consistent RESTful CRUD approach:
* POST /api/royalty_sources: Add a new royalty source (DSP
* GET /api/royalty_sources: List all royalty sources (with filters for source_type).
* GET /api/royalty_sources/<source_uuid>: Get details of a specific source.
* DELETE /api/royalty_sources/<source_uuid>: Delete a source (if not linked to statements
* POST /api/royalty_statements: Record a new incoming royalty statement header. (Request body would include royalty_source_id
* GET /api/royalty_statements: List all statements (filterable by source
* GET /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Get a specific statement header (this endpoint could also be designed to optionally fetch its associated lines).
* PUT /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Update statement header info or status.
* DELETE /api/royalty_statements/<statement_uuid>: Delete a statement (this would also delete its lines due to ON DELETE CASCADE in our SQL).
How does the API endpoint outline for royalty_sources and royalty_statements look to you? These tables are essential for knowing where your money is coming from and when the reports arrive.

7. royalty_statement_lines Table API Endpoints: (This is where your detailed MLC field list is critical!)
* POST /api/statements/<statement_uuid>/lines: Add a new line item to a specific statement. (Request body will be rich: work_id
* GET /api/statements/<statement_uuid>/lines: Get all line items for a specific statement (with pagination/filtering).
* GET /api/works/<work_uuid>/statement_lines: Get all statement lines for a specific work.
* GET /api/sound_recordings/<recording_uuid>/statement_lines: Get all statement lines for a specific sound recording.
* PUT /api/statement_lines/<line_uuid>: Update a specific statement line.
* We'll want robust filtering here by DSP
* POST /api/accrued_royalties/calculate_from_statement/<statement_uuid>: A special action endpoint. The backend will:
1.  Fetch all royalty_statement_lines for the given statement_uuid.
3.  Look up the work_participants for the work_id (and/or sound_recording_id).

work_participants: Links works/recordings to contacts with their specific roles and shares.
royalty_statements: Records for each statement you receive (including an overall source_distribution_date).
royalty_statement_lines: Detailed earnings per work/recording on each statement (tailored for MLC data
accrued_royalties: Calculated earnings due to each specific participant you administer.
payouts: Records of payments you make to your participants.

column1: Let's "GO GO GO" and outline the APIs for the final 3 crucial tables that handle the detailed earnings and payouts:
7. royalty_statement_lines Table API Endpoints: (This is where your detailed MLC field list is critical!)
* POST /api/statements/<statement_uuid>/lines: Add a new line item to a specific statement. (Request body will be rich: work_id
* GET /api/statements/<statement_uuid>/lines: Get all line items for a specific statement (with pagination/filtering).
* GET /api/works/<work_uuid>/statement_lines: Get all statement lines for a specific work.
* GET /api/sound_recordings/<recording_uuid>/statement_lines: Get all statement lines for a specific sound recording.
* PUT /api/statement_lines/<line_uuid>: Update a specific statement line.
* We'll want robust filtering here by DSP
* POST /api/accrued_royalties/calculate_from_statement/<statement_uuid>: A key action endpoint. The backend will:
1.  Fetch all royalty_statement_lines for the given statement_uuid.
3.  Look up the work_participants for the work_id (and/or sound_recording_id).

column2: apply their collection_percentage to the line's royalty_amount.

column1: 5.  Create new records in accrued_royalties for each participant's calculated share.
* GET /api/accrued_royalties: List accrued royalties (filterable by contact_id of the ultimate payee
* GET /api/contacts/<contact_uuid>/accrued_royalties?status=Unpaid: Get all unpaid royalties for a participant.
* POST /api/payouts: Record a new payout you've made. (Request body: contact_id of payee
* Advanced: This could also take a list of accrued_royalties.ids covered by this payout
